ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NATIONAL SERVICE
(Registration of non-citizens)


    1. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister, of Defence how many non-citizens, who, are permanent residents and who are within the call-up age group, have registered for National

Column: 646

Service at the Manpower Base, and how many of them have been called up.

    The Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 5th March this year, 3,338 non-citizens have been registered. None have been called up for full-time National Service as registration is not completed. This is expected to be completed by 20th March. After that date, there will be call-up in three intakes commencing July this year.

Column: 647

HAWKERS CENTRE IN SEMBAWANG
(Building of)


    2. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for the Environment when his Ministry proposes to build a hawkers centre in the Sembawang Constituency.

    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has allocated $10 million for the construction of hawkers centres. These centres will be built in areas to serve the `needs of workers for cooked food, to relieve congestion by street hawkers, and to control water pollution. While we are concentrating on the urban areas where the problem of hawking is more acute, we are not neglecting the rural areas. Wherever there is a real need for one, a hawkers centre will be built.

    The Member for Sembawang may be pleased to note that the Ministry proposes to build a cooked food centre near Chong Pang Police Station. A site has been earmarked for this purpose, and the Hawkers Branch and the P.W.D, are now working out the details.

Column: 647

JTC FLATS IN NAVAL BASE
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Finance how many housing units the Jurong Town Corporation proposes to build at Naval Base in the Sembawang Constituency; when the units will be completed; and how many applications for those units have been received to date.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Jurong Town Corporation proposes to build a total of 1,100 units of flats in the 17-acre site at Sembawang Road. These 1,100 units are being built in two phases as follows: Phase I - 528 units consisting of 440 units of three-room flats and 88 units of four-room flats; and Phase II - 572 units, most of which will be four-room flats. The 528 units now under construction in Phase I are expected to be ready for occupation by the end of this year. Up to 28th February,

Column: 648

1973, 559 applications to purchase these units have been received.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I do not have the figures of the cost; but if the Member wishes, I will send a written reply to him.

    Head 0108 --

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr. Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0108 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1080.

    Sir, the establishment of a special Commercial Offences Investigation Department with specially qualified staff to investigate commercial crimes in Singapore is a long overdue measure. However, my original expectation, and perhaps those of others too, had been that this would mean giving the Commercial Crimes Department of the Police a real skilled and qualified fraud squad, and that it would also mean raising that unfortunate department from the status it has acquired in the Police itself, i.e, of being a sort of elephants' graveyard, to a more respectable condition. But now, for better or for worse, the Commercial Offences Investigation Department has been wedded to the Attorney-General's Chambers.

    Could we know what advantages there are in this measure? And how, will the obvious necessity of liaison with the Police and other organisations, like the Monetary Authority of Singapore, the Registrar of Companies, and so on, be effected? Does it also mean, Sir, that the newly passed Securities Industry Bill will be partly the responsibility of this Unit in the Attorney-General's Chambers?

Column: 651



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon): Mr Speaker, Sir, it was found that commercial offences in Singapore were becoming more varied and sophisticated. The facilities of the Commercial Crimes Branch of the Police as presently constituted were inadequate to cope with the problem. It was therefore decided to create a new department called the Commercial Offences Investigation Department, which will have a staff consisting not only of Police officers but also of lawyers and accountants. The functions of this department will be to investigate offences under the Companies Act and the Securities Industry Act, as well as to investigate offences of cheating, criminal breach of trust, falsification of accounts, forgery and other offences of a commercial nature.

    Although the Estimates have provided for a new department under the Attorney-General's Chambers, the objectives can equally be met by an expansion and restructuring of the existing Commercial Crimes Branch under the Commissioner of Police. The Police prefer to do this and the Attorney-General has no objections. A final decision on this question is expected to be made shortly.

    Mr Conceicao: Sir, in view of the Parliamentary Secretary's answer, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Mr Conceicao: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0108 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2001.

    Sir, I am sorry that this query regarding accidents involving Government vehicles seems to be cropping up from year to year. In 1970 the matter was raised by me during the Budget session and the Minister for Law and National Development agreed that drivers of Government vehicles should set a good example in courtesy and caution on the road. Last year the Member for Punggol also raised this

Column: 652

question and expressed his concern in this regard. The fact that I am raising it again this year is, I think, an indication that nothing much seems to have been done `with regard to improving the standards of driving by drivers of Government vehicles, and to courtesy and caution on the road; although in the case of the Singapore Armed Forces vehicles, their drivers have shown some improvement. Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary could enlighten us in this regard.

    I think we should emphasise as often as possible the importance of courtesy and caution on the road and I am prepared to raise this matter again next year, as the result so far seems to be unsatisfactory.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the amounts incurred over the last three financial years in settling claims arising out of accidents involving Government vehicles in cases which did not go to trial, and the number of such cases are:

    1970-71, there were 224 cases in all, and the amount paid out was $87,667.89.

    1971-72, there were 194 cases in all, and the amount paid out was $72,091.92.

    1972-73 (March), there were 237 cases in all, and the amount paid out was $124,742.87.

These figures show that the number of cases that have been settled remains at a steady level, although the amounts expended have increased. This is attributable to the fact that the average sum involved in each case has increased rather sharply. Drivers of Government vehicles involved in accidents through their negligence are subject to departmental proceedings with a view to disciplinary action in cases of proven negligence.

    In the case of the Ministry of Defence vehicles, the drivers are not only liable to disciplinary proceedings but may also be ordered to pay or contribute towards the cost of the repair of their vehicles. Improvements have also been made to the training

Column: 653

courses which these drivers have to undergo.

    All these measures to try and reduce the number of accidents arising out of negligence are additional to the work planned by the National Safety First Council, the Traffic Police, and the Registrar of Vehicles, to obtain a better all-round standard of driving, courtesy and safety on our roads. However, these figures do not cover the position in respect of the various statutory boards which come under the general direction of various Ministries. If the Member would give notice of a question, we can try and get the necessary information on the extent of the problem and the steps taken to reduce the accident rates.

    Mr Conceicao: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will take advantage of the invitation extended by the Parliamentary Secretary to ask the question which he has advised me to ask. In view of that, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Head 0201 -

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr. Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0201 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001.

    Sir, last year I raised the issue of the Prime Minister's salary, to which the Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office, replied [Hansard, Volume 31, No. 11, col. 704, dated 17th March, 1972] by quoting Hansard, Volume 30, No. I, col. 8, dated 7th May, 1970, at paragraph 5, which reads as follows:

    `I am not increasing my own salary of $3,500 a month. My salary will stay as it is until the end of 1972, by which time Singapore should have overcome the economic problems caused by the rundown in British military expenditure, provided we all work hard for higher and higher productivity and more and more industries.'

I am not particular about the Prime Minister's salary as such, but since he had already stated that it would stay

Column: 654

until the end of 1972, I must, therefore, bring it up again. It is only a few weeks ago that the salaries of top civil servants were increased by a great percentage. Some of them were, in fact, given more than double their former salaries. I feel that it is time our Prime Minister's pay be increased in proportion to the recent pay rise for civil servants; and it should not be lower than a Minister's pay. Our economy is booming, and I am sure that our Prime Minister, on looking at our economy, can afford to smile now.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the matter is now under consideration.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0201 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1041.

    Since anti-pollution measures were introduced about three years ago, air pollution in Singapore has been considerably reduced. I believe three scientists were sent abroad for training specially to counter pollution.

    However, I wish to know, more about the mysterious haze which had been "misting" our environment off and on sometime ago, which experience we have not had for many years. During the time it happened a number of people complained of irritation in their eyes. The only reason given for that appearance of haze was that there was a forest fire in Sumatra. Whether this is true or not has not been verified. Even now we seem to feel that our air is not clean. I wonder whether the Ministry of the Environment is planning anything to counter pollution of the air. Otherwise later on the polluted air might affect the health of our people and give rise to greater problems. Probably, in the future, we may have to wear gas-masks in this, smog-affected island.

Column: 655



    There is another point that I wish to raise. I believe that sea pollution comes under the jurisdiction of another department. But what about smoke emitted from the funnels of some vessels? This seems to be the responsibility of another department. In, any case, what precautionary measures are taken against air pollution caused by the smoke of some of the vessels coming into our port?

    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson may not have been aware that the Ministry of the Environment did issue on 11th October, 1972, a press statement on the subject of haze over Singapore. It advised people not to be unduly concerned about the haze which spread over a very large area in this region. It also pointed out that it was not of local origin and that it was not photo-chemical smog. This was confirmed by the Anti-Pollution Unit whose air monitoring station did not indicate any increase in the pollution level except for a reduction in visibility.

    I would like to assure the Member for Anson that the level of air pollution in Singapore is permissible and under control, though he may feel otherwise. We use scientific instruments to measure the pollutants and the level of various pollutants, particularly sulphur dioxide, and oxidant which cause photo-chemical smog, as monitored by the Anti-Pollution Unit, is still low and well within the international air pollution standards and criteria.

    With regard to the question of smarting eyes, if the Member for Anson can be more specific and give more details, then an investigation will be carried out. But' I doubt whether the cause is due to air pollution in Singapore. I would like to remind him, however, that there are many causes to smarting eyes, e.g, cigarette smoke, spicy food, late nights and not enough sleep and, last but not least, conjunctivitis. If anyone should suffer from conjunctivitis, I would suggest that he refer it to a doctor or see the Minister for Health!

Column: 656



    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has given an explanation which I think is not very clear. How did the haze come to Singapore? Has anything been done with the other Government to prevent the haze from coming to Singapore? I do not think so. The Minister only replied that "we are doing everything possible to see that it is all right." But the Minister, in replying to my question, should have said, "We will try to do something about that." Then I would accept it. But it is all right in any case.

    Sir, the boundaries of the electoral divisions should be properly checked and voters who have removed from one place to another should have their change of addresses recorded immediately in the Register; otherwise, when voting day comes, these voters will not be able to vote. In fact, this happened during the last elections, when so many voters complained that they did not receive their voting cards. A voting card may show that a voter is staying in Hoe Chiang Road, but he may have to go to Jurong to vote. But he might already have gone to Hoe Chiang Road to vote, only to find that he has to go to Jurong to vote. Or it may even be Hoe Chiang Road! That is the trouble many voters have experienced. Why is it so? The names of the roads and also the names of the polling stations must be properly checked and recorded. I want this done, Sir.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, for the information of the Member for Anson, when a voter changes his address, he must report directly to the

Column: 657

Commissioner of National Registration or to those community centres designated for this purpose. At the moment, there are 82 centres in 63 constituencies to which they can make a report of a change of address. All these reported changes of address are notified to the Elections Department, which will then compile a list known as List B. A separate List B will be compiled for each of the 65 electoral divisions and will be exhibited for public inspection for a period of 14 days upon an annual revision of the Registers of Electors. This annual revision of Registers is always announced on TV, over radio and the press. I therefore advise every voter to inspect the electoral registers at any of these 82 centres, whenever it is announced that these registers are open for public inspection. Every elector who has reported a change of address should also inspect the Registers of Electors during such an annual revision.

    In addition, members of the public can always go to the Elections Department at City Hall to seek advice on this and other election matters. Further, whenever an election takes place, polling cards are sent to all electors at their last known official addresses. Those who fail to receive polling cards can go to the Elections Department for such cards.

    Head 0301 --

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0301 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001.

    Sir, in the past, there has been a lot of talk about making Singapore a brain centre in South-east Asia. What efforts

Column: 658

have been made to this effect? We have quite a number of students going abroad for further studies. There is no doubt that Singapore cannot cope with certain fields of study. However, I wonder why many of our students still go abroad for their basic studies, facilities for which are available in Singapore. Obviously, they are either dissatisfied with the facilities available here or that many facilities are not available. All this talk about making Singapore a brain centre should show more concrete forms. We should put in more effort into what has been planned so that Singapore can truly be a brain centre.

    The Minister for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng): Mr Speaker, Sir, on the question of making Singapore as a brain centre, there are various developments towards this objective. The Applied Research Corporation at the Ministry of Science and Technology for Services in applied scientific and technological research, the International Development and Engineering Construction Organisation at the Ministry of National Development for engineering and allied services, and the various developments in medical specialities are some of the examples of our efforts to make Singapore a brain centre in this part of the world.

    With regard to the Member's query on the large number of students going overseas, let me assure him that the institutions of higher learning in Singapore are one of the best equipped and staffed in this region. However, there are various reasons for students going overseas. We can divide them into various categories. Firstly, there are those who are on scholarship awarded by foreign governments and they are required to study in those countries. Secondly, there are those who go overseas for post-graduate research, either on scholarship or on their own. Thirdly, there are those who go overseas for subjects not available in Singapore, such as music and aeronautical engineering. And finally, of course, there is the group of people who are on their

Column: 659

fathers' scholarships, and they go overseas because they cannot gain admission into our institutions of higher learning. The number of this category of people amounts to no more, than one-fifth of the number who go overseas.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I am happy with the explanation given by the Minister. I beg leave to withdraw.

What sort of research is being done with Grants amounting to $90,000, and whether this research is in relation to the Applied Research Corporation which the Minister referred to just now, or whether this is something else? Where Contract Work is concerned, how is it given, and for what purpose? For the other two items, Patent Search and Miscellaneous, I just want some information, Sir.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Research Grants under this subhead have been provided since 1969 to finance and encourage applied scientific and technological research which are practical and relevant to our industrialisation programme. It is a bit difficult to describe what type of research is being carried out. Perhaps 1 will just quote a few examples: research on telecommunications problems, methods of shielding heat from walls of, high-rise apartments and, design characteristics, of waste disposal, incineration, etc. Each year, project proposals are invited from .the teaching staff and research personnel of our tertiary institutions, for consideration of financial support. Therefore, this is quite different from the Applied Research Corporation which I mentioned just now. The proposals are then evaluated by the Science Council and, upon its recommendations, the Ministry makes the grants.

    Sir, our conversion to the metric system in weights and measures is highly commendable. I would like to know how far has metrication been extended to the hawkers. I hope that during the process of metrication the markets in particular, could be looked into, with careful attention, because there is a tendency for them to carry on a great deal of unfair, means. The daching system of weighing has always rendered the customer the loser. It is hoped that the daching would be entirely got rid off as a system of weighing, and instead a proper balance scale be introduced so as to reduce the possibility of cheating.

    Furthermore, with the promotion of metrication, may I suggest that each market be provided with a spring balance weighing machine where members of the public can check the weight of the food they buy.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Sir, at the outset, we recognise the difficulties involved in introducing metrication at the retail trade level. That is why the White Paper presented to Parliament in 1970 recommended that the metrication in the retail trade be allowed to be implemented over a period of time. Notwithstanding this, we have been able to introduce metrication into certain trades, e.g. petroleum, textile, etc.

    With, regard to the suggestion for the provision of weighing machines by the Government, I understand that a large number of Government markets at the moment do provide weighing machines calibrated in the customary units for

Column: 661

the benefit of the customers. As and when the metric system is introduced into the markets and the retail trade, this will be provided for.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,
